sentence: Futures point to a slightly lower open at this morning's bell, with some profit taking and nagging global concerns keeping a somewhat dampened outlook following a big day in the green on Monday.
Also, retailers continue their onslaught of quarterly earnings releases, as we see results this morning from Macy's ( M ) and Home Depot ( HD ), among others.
This helps frame the question: Where are Americans spending their money?

At first glance, it would look like retailers in general have benefited from a more confident consumer, though if you see Macy's year-over-year revenues coming in lower - like we saw with Nordstrom ( JWN ) last week - even as the company beat analyst expectations on the top and bottom lines.
This has sent Macy's shares up as much as 7 percent following its earnings announcement before the bell today.
Then again, consider that Macy's shares are still down more than 30 percent since this time last year.
Home Depot also beat estimates for earnings and sales on a record Q4 ahead of Tuesday's opening bell, with revenues posting a Array0 percent upside from last year at this time.
Year-over-year comps were up roughly 9 percent.

This would indicate that even though an apparel/fashion retailer like Macy's performed well in its earnings report (even though its guidance was down), a home improvement center like Home Depot has performed even better.
Perhaps we can conclude at this stage that we're seeing more demand from consumers interested in fixing up their houses than chasing the latest trends in couture.
Regarding where Americans are spending more to live these days, new Case-Shiller Index data for December was released this morning, with home pricing up 5.4 percent year over year overall.
The 20-city composite was 5.7 percent, down a couple ticks from the 5.9 percent expected.
Pricing strength has grown highest out West: Portland, OR, San Francisco and Denver saw the biggest gains - all 3 cities saw double-digit pricing growth.
Overall results from November to December were unchanged.
Americans are also spending their time following the early primaries in the 20Array6 Presidential race.
Republicans are holding their Nevada caucuses today following a big win by Donald Trump Saturday in South Carolina.
Trump being in the hotel and casino business would likely help him win among voters in Las Vegas, Reno, etc.

But Nevada is also home to multi-billionaire and conservative activist Sheldon Adelson, who reportedly spent $Array00 million in the 20Array2 election and has thus far kept mum on which candidate he supports.
On the other side of the aisle, though Hillary Clinton enjoys a lead on the Democratic side over challenger Bernie Sanders, the delegate count remains close at this stage.
Democrats in South Carolina get ready to bring out the vote this Saturday, which is predicted to be a big win for Clinton.

Finally, we have confirmation from United Technologies ( UTX ) that a mega-merger with Honeywell ( HON ) was indeed on the table, although the high-tech conglomerate has decided not to pursue the deal, citing concerns regarding Federal regulations, valuation issues and other obstacles.
The merger may not have passed anti-trust rulings in any case, which may have been the final straw for the corporations.
